Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 09:32AM kingjr66 wrote: yes, my breasts are very dense and riddled with cysts.  I am cancer free at the moment but they are monitoring me closely, hense all the mammos and MRI's.  I just feel that any mass, no matter what type, I don't want in there.  I know that they tell me about unecessary surgery, and that these atypia cells may not be cancer (last pathology report came back benign), but how will I know if/when they do turn to cancer if I leave them in there?  How long do I wait until they tell me that it has to come out.  I guess I will need to drill my surgeon or find another one.  Thank you for your reply and support. Linda
Posts.Title: atypia cells keep growing back - what to do? kingjr66 kingjr66

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 02:42PM kingjr66 wrote: I feel for everyone that I have read so far on this website.  My experiences are so much less than yours and others but I know that my history with this is not over and never will be.  The screening is so important but I would much prefer a yearly MRI since the mammos have not detected the cell mass.  They seem like a waste of time.  I was very suprised to learn that the cells had grown back in such a short amount of time and to be told that this is normal.  I do not believe that any mass in a breast is normal and never should be taken lightly.  My surgeon is one of the best in my area but I do question her ethnics in explaining the results to me.  I thank you for your reply and your support.  I wish I could give back more info but I am a nubie and just learning about all this and where it might take me in the future.  Linda
Posts.Title: atypia cells keep growing back - what to do? kingjr66 kingjr66

Posts.Content: kingjr66 wrote: Approximatly 2 years ago I had a small mass removed. This mass was not seen on any prior mammograms and only seen on MRI. Was not seen also on follow up ultrasound so they removed it.  pathology confirmed flat epithelial atypia, benign. I have educated myself and know what I am dealing with.  My last MRI in April 2011 showed that this mass "persists", but my surgeon told me that I have a normal MRI ???  Second opinion doctor concurs with radioligist that there is another mass but since 1st mass removed was benign that my fears should not get the best of me.  I understand this as well.  He also recommended that I get a follow up ultrasound but my current surgeon put me back on schedule for a 6 month follow up mammogram, which I am due to have in approx 2-3 weeks.  A little history background.  Mom had cancer removed 33 years ago.  She had full mastectomy and has been cancer free since (great insperation).  Father's sister died of breast cancer.  I have had 4 mammos and 2 MRI in the past 2 years, not counting the MRI and mammogram done on the day of surgery. I also had needle biopsy on other breat which is a fibroadenoma but doctor will not take out. Not concerned about that but it does sit on a nerve and gives me some awful pain from time to time. I am very diligent on these screenings since my doctor feels I am in a higher risks factor.  Since I will be seeing my surgeon after the mammogram I will have some questions and my last MRI in hand. Should I insist to have this new mass of cells taken out? Ultarasound sounds useless since could not see it first time. Do I wait another year for the next MRI? These mammos every 6 months only show all the cysts and not these particular cells.  Any suggestions?  I am quite educated on the conditions of my breasts. Looking to see if anyone else with same senario. The mind has tremedous healing power. Never give up. Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 05:57PM kingjr66 wrote: My doctor is a breast surgeon.  I have also gotten a second surgical opinion.  He concurs that the cells have grown back but my doctor has not scheduled me for this second surgery.  I'm told that since first pathology report come back benign, that I should not worry myself over this new cell growth, yeah right!  My surgeon is a firm believer in not performing any unnecessary surgery. She will not take out a large fibroadenoma in the other breast even though it causes pain.  I think it is pinching/sitting on a nerve.  I'm sure at some point the atypia cell growth will have to be removed but the waiting is nerve racking.  My blood pressure has spike due to this stress. Had yet another mammo yesterday and an ultrasound.  Will have results in couple days.  Already know what they will find, dense breasts, alot of cysts, the fibroadenoma, but no cell growths.  It's always the same on my mammos, can only see the atypia cells on MRI.  Would like to know more about the long term affects of all these mammo screenings.  Anyone have any research on this topic?

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2011 04:16AM kingjr66 wrote: sherryc - you're right the choices are mine.  I am seeing her on the 22nd for results of mammo and ultra sound I had couple days ago.  Of course I will have that report in hand come Monday.  I never wait to see the doctor, never can get apptm for a least 2 wks after testing anyway.  After reading topics and discussions from this website, many ladies have convinced me that I do not have to settle on just one doctor.  I have gotten opinions from several technicians that my doctor is a stick-in-the-mud and very conservative about unnecessary surgery.  Heck with that, they are my breasts, my stress, my choice.  thank you.

Posts.Title: atypia cells keep growing back - what to do? kingjr66 kingjr66

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 03:18AM kingjr66 wrote: Hi SueJr: I too had a mass not seen on mammogram or ultrasound.  Mine was not felt since it sat behind the milk ducts.  You are doing the right thing by having it removed and sent for pathology.  I'm not sure why though you need to wait 2 months.  Sometimes surgeons schedules are full, but 2 months?  Could be waiting to see of any changes.  Please keep a positive mind.  Although my outcome was not good, I was able to find my cancer in it's early stage and that is the key.  Keep your mind focused and always think good things.  The mind is a very powerful healing tool and is the best medicine.  Good Luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 06:51AM kingjr66 wrote: Thank you for sharing this video clip.  I have extremely dense breasts and my mass was only seen on mri. Because of my density, I now have available to me a yearly mri and a yearly mammogram.  This new inovation seems quite incredible prompting me to further look into this new screening method.  I hope to see this type of screening available in the near future.
Posts.Title: Hope for Dense Breasts Shanagirl Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 07:44AM - edited Feb 4, 2012 07:46AM by kingjr66 klg49:  I have had fibro for years.  I too have vitamin D deficiency and taking 50,000 units but I continue to take mine.  The Prozac is very common to give to fibro patients.  It puts you in a deep realm sleep so that you body can heal.  Sleep is the best medicine for severe pain.  The drawback on the Prozac is that it can make you crazy, literally.  That's why you see all those warnings on anti-depressants that "thoughts of suicide can occur".  Be very careful if deciding to take this medication.  Exercise is good for fibro.  Walking is the best and some light stretching.  Your yoga is good too.  Takes time to feel results.  Would like to ask, are you taking any anti-cholesterol meds?  These are very very bad for fibro people, actually anyone in general.  The FDA has come out with warnings for people who take high doses and have taken them for years that it deteriorates your muscles. I stopped taking mine and gradually felt better. I have high cholesterol but fish oil is a great substitute for the meds. One last thing. I have researched this disease for many years. I have not come to any conclusion yet as to how people are inflicted with this, but have read many articles of research and some believe that this is a chemical imbalance in the brain caused by a severe emotional trauma. Of course a diagnosis of cancer is truly a shocking discovery and the years of emotional termoil that follow. Mine was the untimely death of my brother.  And then when I learned of my cancer the fibro symptoms kicked into high gear so there my be some truth as to the emotional stress syndrome.  Your mind has a unbelieveable healing power.  Sometimes thinking good thoughts can give comfort.  It's hard when you feel so bad.  My favorite saying is "mind of matter".  I wish the best for you an hope for pain free days for you and everyone.
Posts.Title: Chemo/Radiation and Fibromyalgia kingjr66 FLislander

Posts.Content: kingjr66 wrote: Hello Ladies:  I was wondering if there are any of you out there than can not take Tamoxifen or any of the other hormone therapies?  I am told that I can not take Tamoxifen.  I have very strong family history of blood clots and pulmonary embolisms.  I am 51 and still ovulate and was told that I would need to be put into post menopause.  I was offered removal of my ovaries or a shot of something.  I was not paying close attention to the "shot of something"  since I was still trying to take in the removal part.  I was previously told several weeks ago that I would need chemo but had oncotype dx and my score was 13.  This all seems too much since I have a very good prognosis.  I was given only an 8% chance of recurrence of this cancer and a 15% chance of any other cancer forming.  I still am waiting on my brca test results.  Surely because of my age I may be post menopause pretty soon.  My mom done at age 46 and my sister 50.  Any advice from similar situations? The mind has tremedous healing power. Never give up. Posts.Title: Can't take Tamoxifen kingjr66 hhillmontana

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2012 03:27PM kingjr66 wrote: I start my 6 weeks of rads next week and I have early stage BC.  I agree with several others regarding the length of treatment no matter what your stage is.  Treatment is targeted at the whole breast to kill possible cells that have jumped to other sites in the breast.  Would like to inject my thoughts on mammosite radiation.  I was offered this treatment and did a very thorough research on it.  Yes, less treatment appointments but what I learned is that women who have had this treatment reported apporx 2 years later that they have cyst growth at the site of seed implant.  They also report pain at the site.  They then have to have the cyst drained/biopsied.  This can occur several times.  They are constantly in pain and stressed from having to go through biopsy after biopsy.  I encourge everyone to do their own research.  I opted for the 6 weeks.
Posts.Title: Radiation Therapy for early stage Kaara mimikitty

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 05:13PM kingjr66 wrote: hello kennelmom:  hematoma is very common after biopsy.  yes, there can be a lump.  this is blood that is rising to your skin surface and should go away shortly, could last for a week.  I suffer from bad bruising, so I know a thing or two about hematomas and mine usually are huge and last for weeks.  My biopsies where the worse that I ever had.  I took pictures because I just could not believe that my whole breast was one huge mass of purple, blue and red color. Of course you can always call your doctor's office for their advice.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2012 08:10AM kingjr66 wrote: hello sam:  I'm a firm believer in mind over matter.  I've tried the pills, the pt, and therapy.  All I got for it was 50 lbs overweight (steroids), sorer muscles (pt) and negative thoughts (therapy).  I told myself one day that I'm not going to take this anymore.  I threw away the pills, stopped the pt and therapy and believe it or not I started to feel better.  I took control of my mind to stop all the negativity.  Until my bc diagnosis.  It's happening all over again.  I ache from head to toe and the breathing and stress relief techniques are not working.  I know I have to heal from the bc first before I can get relief from fm.  But I'm back to the waiting game for testing results.  Hoping there is more advice.  Thanks.
Posts.Title: Chemo/Radiation and Fibromyalgia kingjr66 FLislander

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2012 05:13AM kingjr66 wrote: Emaline:  Unfortunately I was a bleeder.  Yup, first breast biopsy was the colorful one.  Then 1st surgery I bruised pretty bad.  Then I popped open my incission after a week and bled so bad had to go ER (I blame the surgeon on that one, probably nicked a few blood vessels when in there and shoddy stiches)(who by the way misdiagnosed my cancer-can't get into that one).  Then second biopsy I had to go back next day because I could not stop bleeding.  This prompted set of blood tests to see if I had any blood disorder, all negative.  One good thing about bleeding out, I had very little bruising since all the blood came out instead of under the skin.  Then 2nd surgery to remove cancer all went well.  Just one small bruise.  This surgeon was great and took into account that I am a bleeder and probably took her time, no nicked blood vessels.  Laura: keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 04:37PM kingjr66 wrote: I was just given a blow to the gut.  Met my onocologist for 1st time today.  She is suggesting chemo first.  I just about threw up.  I was given an option however to have a oncotype dx test done.  This is a genomic test to see the likelyhoold of my cancer recurring whether in the breast or somewhere else in my body.  I told her to go for it.  It it comes back with low # then I can forgo the chemo.  If the # is high then I will need chemo.  She still said that even if # high, it is my choice since I have low grade cancer.  And here I was all ready to start my rads on the 23rd.  They just cancelled my first 2 weeks since this test is done in California and will take almost 2 weeks.  I'm keeping my fingers crossed.
